Your first paragraph should define what the paper is about, the pro’s and con’s of your research. Take two paragraphs if you must. The subsequent paragraphs should address the points you mentioned in the first paragraph in the same order, but in much more detail. Your last paragraph is your closing argument/comments/conclusion, it is the paragraph that you will address briefly all the previous points (in the same order) to prove or disprove what your subject is about. (check out online: owl perdue, you must determine if your paper is an essay or a scientific research paper, for which the paper needs to be formated accordingly (where to indent a paragraph where not to, margins, the use of bold or italics, that sort of thing) once you know the right format, writing can become a joy. Best of luck!

First you must identify a problem. Then you must make sure that your research is original, meaning you must look through tons of research papers in the same arena of thought that you want to do research in. Next come the fun of abstracts and hypothesis, conducting the research and recording data. Lastly you write your results, and a conclusion to explain your results.

You don't write research. You do it. And then if you write papers about what you did and what you got out of what you did. If you are lucky either of them will be interesting/unique/currently in. That will give you a paper. And if you are really lucky, you might be even able to explain your result. thanks for A2A
